WESTMORELAND — Water at Maplewood Nursing Home tested positive
for E. coli on Tuesday, county officials said Wednesday.
Officials were notified this afternoon by the N.H. Department of
Environmental Services of a boil water order issued immediately for
the water system at the nursing home.
Maplewood, the county-owned nursing home, is on a different
water system than the rest Westmoreland and no other water users
are affected, according to John G. Wozmak, county
Bottled water and store-bought ice will be arriving this evening
and water stations will be set up on each residential floor,
The nursing home’s water is tested regularly. After Tuesday’s
positive reading, more water was tested Wednesday. No health
problems related to E. coli have been reported.

column1:
On August 23, the East Coast shook with a 5.8 magnitude earthquake centered in Mineral, Virginia.

Since then, millions in disaster aid funds have been spent cleaning up after the natural disaster.

But some residents in one Fauquier County town are still without a basic service: potable tap water.

Residents in Bealeton have told News4 that water out of the tap has been unsafe to drink since the quake hit last summer.  The earthquake damaged one of the wells in the town's water system, and a permanent fix has yet to be put in place.

According to the Fauquier Water and Sanitation Authority, 1,304 customers were affected when part of the seal on the Mintbrook well, part of Bealeton's water system, was damaged during the quake.  The well sits in the middle of a cow pasture, and the damage has allowed rainwater to seep down from the surface down into the well.

In October, the Water and Sanitation Authority sent out a notice to customers warning them of elevated levels of coliform bacteria and e. coli in the water.  Residents were advised then to boil their water to keep from getting sick.  The notice said that a fix would be in place by November.

But those early efforts were unsuccessful, and the affected residents are still under a boil water notice.  WSA told News4 that since then, a new well has been dug.  In the latest notice, residents were told the new water system will be online by the end of March.

But WSA says if the well passes health inspections, it could be operational sooner.

Meanwhile, 1,304 customers will be getting an apology of sorts in their next water bill - a credit for 1,000 gallons of water, equivalent to about a third of the average water bill.

column1:
Connecticut Water lifted a boil water advisory in Hebron Tuesday afternoon.

The water company had advised about 78 customers of the London Park water system in Hebron to boil water after an equipment failure Monday.

Customers were affected on Carolyn Drive, Jan Drive, Laura Drive and London Road.  They were being urged to boil their tap water before using it for drinking, cooking and food preparation.

The advisory was issued as a precaution because of an equipment failure that allowed the pressure in the water system to drop below 20 pounds per square inch.

Connecticut Water officials tested the water, and results Tuesday showed the water was safe to drink, according to Connecticut Water.

If you have any questions, call The Connecticut Water Company at 1-800-286-5700 or check the company’s Web site.

HEBRON — The  Connecticut Water Co. has rescinded its boil water advisory for the London Park water system, which serves 78 customers on Carolyn, Jan, and Laura drives and London Road.

The utility said Tuesday that it has confirmed that the water is safe to drink and use for all other purposes. Customers no longer need to take any precautions before using their tap water, the company said.

Water samples were collected after water service had been restored Monday following the repair of a broken fitting at the well. The samples were tested in a state-certified laboratory, which confirmed the water’s potability.
“Connecticut Water appreciates the patience of customers while worked to restore service and then to test the water to confirm its quality,” spokesman Dan Meaney said.
Customers may call Connecticut Water’s customer service staff at 1-800-286-5700 if they have any questions. Information is also available on the company’s web site,

Update: 12:05 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city officials say there has been another small water main break, totaling to nine water main breaks in Lynchburg Thursday.{\/p}

-------------{\/p}

Update: 11:45 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city crews have already fixed two water main breaks and are dealing with six more Tuesday.{\/p}

Residents who live in the affected areas will receive boil water advisories from the city.{\/p}

One of the breaks was on Link Road, which was closed for a little while this morning. That break has been fixed as well as one on Ivy Link Road.{\/p}

Officials say that's the original break, and it led to the seven after it.{\/p}

There are still problems on Clayton Avenue, Gorman Road, Woodcrest Drive, Trents Ferry Road, Rivermont Avenue and Bonair Circle.{\/p}

Again, a boil water advisory will be hand-delivered to residents Tuesday.{\/p}

----------------{\/p}

Update: 10:50 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg's Department of Water Resources is reporting several water main breaks throughout the Rivermont and Boonsboro Road areas.{\/p}

City officials this includes portions of Link and Trents Ferry Roads, VES, Mimosa and areas around Bedford Hills School, the Boonsboro Shopping Center and Virginia Baptist Hospital. {\/p}

Customers may experience low water pressure, discolored water, or water service disruptions. {\/p}

City officials say crews are working to restore service as quickly as possible. {\/p}

-------------------{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - The 1500-1800 block of Link Road is closed and city officials don't know when it will be back open. The road is shut down so city crews can repair a water main break.{\/p}

ABC 13 News will keep you informed as to when Link Road is open again.{\/p}""}

Update: 12:05 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city officials say there has been another small water main break, totaling to nine water main breaks in Lynchburg Thursday.{\/p}

-------------{\/p}

Update: 11:45 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city crews have already fixed two water main breaks and are dealing with six more Tuesday.{\/p}

Residents who live in the affected areas will receive boil water advisories from the city.{\/p}

One of the breaks was on Link Road, which was closed for a little while this morning. That break has been fixed as well as one on Ivy Link Road.{\/p}

Officials say that's the original break, and it led to the seven after it.{\/p}

There are still problems on Clayton Avenue, Gorman Road, Woodcrest Drive, Trents Ferry Road, Rivermont Avenue and Bonair Circle.{\/p}

Again, a boil water advisory will be hand-delivered to residents Tuesday.{\/p}

----------------{\/p}

Update: 10:50 p.m.:{\/strong}{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg's Department of Water Resources is reporting several water main breaks throughout the Rivermont and Boonsboro Road areas.{\/p}

City officials this includes portions of Link and Trents Ferry Roads, VES, Mimosa and areas around Bedford Hills School, the Boonsboro Shopping Center and Virginia Baptist Hospital. {\/p}

Customers may experience low water pressure, discolored water, or water service disruptions. {\/p}

City officials say crews are working to restore service as quickly as possible. {\/p}

-------------------{\/p}

Lynchburg, VA - The 1500-1800 block of Link Road is closed and city officials don't know when it will be back open. The road is shut down so city crews can repair a water main break.{\/p}

ABC 13 News will keep you informed as to when Link Road is open Update: Another Water Main Break, Two Fixed

Crews Working Tuesday Morning
column2:
body=You%20should%20read%20this!%0A%0Ahttp://wset.com/archive/crews-fix-two-of-eight-water-main-breaks"">

Update: 12:05 p.m.:

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city officials say there has been another small water main break, totaling to nine water main breaks in Lynchburg Thursday.

-------------

Update: 11:45 p.m.:

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg city crews have already fixed two water main breaks and are dealing with six more Tuesday.

Residents who live in the affected areas will receive boil water advisories from the city.

One of the breaks was on Link Road, which was closed for a little while this morning. That break has been fixed as well as one on Ivy Link Road.

Officials say that's the original break, and it led to the seven after it.

There are still problems on Clayton Avenue, Gorman Road, Woodcrest Drive, Trents Ferry Road, Rivermont Avenue and Bonair Circle.

Again, a boil water advisory will be hand-delivered to residents Tuesday.

----------------

Update: 10:50 p.m.:

Lynchburg, VA - Lynchburg's Department of Water Resources is reporting several water main breaks throughout the Rivermont and Boonsboro Road areas.

City officials this includes portions of Link and Trents Ferry Roads, VES, Mimosa and areas around Bedford Hills School, the Boonsboro Shopping Center and Virginia Baptist Hospital.

Customers may experience low water pressure, discolored water, or water service disruptions.

City officials say crews are working to restore service as quickly as possible.

-------------------

Lynchburg, VA - The 1500-1800 block of Link Road is closed and city officials don't know when it will be back open. The road is shut down so city crews can repair a water main break.

ABC 13 News will keep you informed as to when Link Road is open again.

column1: SLLERSBURG, Ind.  (WDRB) -- The Sellersburg water system has lifted a boil water advisory.
That means workers at the Fireside restaurant won't have to use bagged ice or bottled drinks, as they have since Friday.
Fireside is but one of the businesses and homes that was inconvenienced after a construction crew broke a water line on Feb. 10 during construction of a new gas station at U.S. 31 and State Road 60.

""It's very difficult,"" said restaurant owner Neil Smith. ""You lose a lot of your profit centers within your drinks because you have to buy everything or buying all the ice, so it's hard, it's hard on us.""
Officials at Sellersburg's public schools planned to use bottled water Monday and made sure all drinking fountains were covered so they couldn't be used.
West Clark Community Schools trucked in cases of water Friday afternoon, the district's food service director told WDRB.

The water system asked customers to boil water for 15 minutes before drinking and to be careful about laundering whites. Low pressure resulting from the water line break could have caused bacteria to form in the water.
That low pressure also allowed metals from water lines to accumulate in water, hence the brown or tea-colored water that could stain clothing.
The boil advisory was a precaution -- a standard advisory in such conditions.
